newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish Sise Cam exports seen lower in '97.
newsitem.headline: Turkish Sise Cam exports seen lower in '97.

text.p: Turkish glassware producer Sise Cam is aiming for $325 million from its exports in 1997, lower than $339 million realised last year, the company's general manager Adnan Caglayan said on Tuesday.
"We have targeted $325 million worth of exports for 1997," he told a news conference in Istanbul. He did not say why the exports were expected to fall.
He said the company, the biggest in the sector, was planning investment worth $402 million this year after investments of $367 million completed in 1996.
"The investment in the next three years will rise to $1 billion," he said.
He said the investments this year would help company's production rise to 1.4 million tonnes of glass, 1.4 million tonnes of industrial raw material and 633,000 tonnes of soda ash.
He said revenues would reach 352 trillion lira.
He said Sise Cam would seek foreign partnerships "on the eve of the year 2000" in an effort to raise the share of foreign production deals in its total revenues to 10 percent.
He said the company would buy a 25 percent stake from Belgian company Solvay's purchase in December of 60 percent of Bulgaria's privatised soda ash producer SODI for $160 million.
"Therefore Sise Cam will own some 17 percent of SODI and will get 250,000 tonnes of its production, which will raise Sise Cam's soda ash production to one million tonnes," he said.
The company has set up an equally-owned chemical company, Oxyvit Kimya, with the Italian company Cromical to produce Vitamin-K, used as additive in animal fodder.

Sise Cam will also be involved in the production of certain glass-fibered plastics, used in construction, automobile, natural gas, electricity distribution and telecommunications sectors, with the German company Mitras. he said.
